author: By Gray Beltran
title: The Week in Business: Travel Troubles
description: Thousands of flight cancellations, a new, shorter isolation period for people with Covid-19 and return to the office plans still in flux.
content: It was a bad week for anyone with a flight to catch. With staff shortages partially driven by the spread of the Omicron variant, many airlines began canceling flights the day before Christmas, and the cancellations continued during the week between Christmas and New Year’s Day. The airlines shoulder some of the blame. While they had begun to fill out the ranks that were thinned early in the pandemic, they have yet to restore their prepandemic work force. Even with all the cancellations, airports were busier than they’ve been since the pandemic began. But the number of people screened at airport security checkpoints around Christmas was still down 18 percent from a comparable period in 2019, according to the Transportation Security Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Maryland prepares for a ‘terrible point’ in the Covid crisis, the governor says.
description: Gov. Larry Hogan said the state was trying to staff hospitals through a variety of measures.
content: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland said Sunday that the next few weeks could be one of the worst periods of the coronavirus epidemic yet, and that the state was working against staffing shortages in “overflowing” hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: South Africa’s Parliament Burns
description: Plus a breach in the DMZ and posturing about women’s rights in China.
content: A large fire damaged much of the Houses of Parliament on Sunday. Officials warned that the damage to the historic complex would be extensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brennan and Giulia Heyward
title: Colorado Residents Ponder the Road Ahead After Wildfires
description: Days after what might be the most damaging wildfire in state history, residents are just beginning to make sense of the long road back and the extent of the damage.
content: LOUISVILLE, Colo. — Kathe Perez can barely process what she lost in the incineration of the three-bedroom home she’s lived in for the past three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: If You Drop It
description: Beth Rubin and Trent H. Evans keep it all inside.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Thank you to Beth Rubin and Trent H. Evans for including the word “giraffe” in one of the clues for this puzzle so that I could use the picture above. Oh, and thank you for this fun puzzle, too!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Vimal Patel
title: 21 People Rescued After a Freezing Night Stranded in Aerial Tram Cars
description: They spent the first hours of 2022 shivering in stalled aerial tram cars on a New Mexico mountain, rationing Life Savers gummies and bottles of water.
content: The restaurant workers walked into the aerial tram car at about 9 p.m. on New Year’s Eve, their shifts complete, their moods festive, even with the lashing wind and heavy snow. Amber Santos stood beside the trash bins they had carried inside the car, which reeked of food leftovers from Ten 3, a restaurant at the top of Sandia Peak near Albuquerque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Venice Gets a Grip on a Star Architect’s Slippery Bridge
description: The city will replace the glass on Santiago Calatrava’s footbridge across the Grand Canal with stone after too many pedestrians fell.
content: VENICE — As tourists wandered obliviously on the glass floor of the footbridge, locals proceeded with caution. Venetians made sure to walk on the narrow stone strip at the center, some lifting fogged glasses to keep their eyes on the ground. When a visitor tripped, they barely lifted their gaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Wellness vacations go beyond massages and diet tips during the pandemic.
description: Before the pandemic, when Mary Calliste, 32, traveled, she would try to hit as many tourist attractions as she could. But in early December, Ms. Calliste, who works in the financial services industry out of Plainfield, N.J., went to Guatemala and stayed at an eco-friendly hotel called Lush Atitlán. There, she ate vegan meals, walked around the natural reserve and listened to music.
content: Before the pandemic, when Mary Calliste, 32, traveled, she would try to hit as many tourist attractions as she could. But in early December, Ms. Calliste, who works in the financial services industry out of Plainfield, N.J., went to Guatemala and stayed at an eco-friendly hotel called Lush Atitlán. There, she ate vegan meals, walked around the natural reserve and listened to music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Puerto Rico Faces Staggering Covid Case Explosion
description: The island had a 4,600 percent increase in cases in recent weeks after mounting one of the nation’s most successful vaccination campaigns.
content: Armed with her vaccine passport and a giddy urge to celebrate the holiday season, Laura Delgado — and 60,000 other people in Puerto Rico — attended a Bad Bunny concert three weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Omicron, Colorado, Betty White: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu
title: Boldface Names Give Los Angeles a New Cultural Center
description: An OMA-designed pavilion at the Wilshire Boulevard Temple was helped along by Eli Broad. It houses Wallis Annenberg’s GenSpace, a center for older people.
content: LOS ANGELES — On a clear December morning, Los Angeles’s greatest hits shine from the roof of the Audrey Irmas Pavilion: You can see the Hollywood sign, the Griffith Park Observatory, even a snowy Mount Baldy, all without squinting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Verizon and AT&T Decline Regulators’ Request to Delay New 5G Services
description: Transportation officials said they feared a risk to flight safety. The standoff could complicate a tumultuous travel period filled with cancellations.
content: Federal transportation officials want AT&T and Verizon to postpone their planned release of expanded 5G wireless services this week, citing fears of signal interference that they said could pose risks to flight safety. On Sunday, the wireless companies responded and said no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Child Tax Credit’s Extra Help Ends, Just as Covid Surges Anew
description: A pandemic benefit that many progressives hoped to make permanent has lapsed in a congressional standoff. Researchers say it spared many from poverty.
content: For millions of American families with children, the 15th of the month took on a special significance in 2021: It was the day they received their monthly child benefit, part of the Biden administration’s response to the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Says Unknown Person Crossed Heavily Armed Border Into North
description: The breach at the Demilitarized Zone went unnoticed for hours, the South Korean military said. There was no immediate response from North Korea.
content: SEOUL — The South Korean military said on Sunday that an unidentified person had crossed the Demilitarized Zone into North Korea, its latest security lapse at one of the world’s most heavily armed borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon
title: Giants Give Up Four Sacks and Jets Falter, as Opponents Overshadow Gains
description: Every week brings the Giants and the Jets closer to the N.F.L. draft.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Goldman Sachs Follows Wall Street Rivals in Asking Staff to Work From Home
description: In a shift in policy as Covid cases rise, the Wall Street firm urged U.S. employees who can work remotely to do so until Jan. 18.
content: Goldman Sachs told its U.S. employees on Sunday to work from home for the first two weeks of the year, joining Wall Street competitors that had already given similar instructions as coronavirus cases have surged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: A Former Facebook Executive Pushes to Open Social Media’s ‘Black Boxes’
description: The co-founder of CrowdTangle has been working with Congress on legislation to make tech companies disclose their inner workings.
content: Brandon Silverman’s last day at Facebook was Oct. 8, and like many others who have sold their companies to a Silicon Valley giant, had their shares vest and departed, he planned to take a year off to spend time with his children and figure out what to do next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Tracking Climate Change in 193 Countries
description: A team of more than 40 Opinion writers, photographers and editors spent five months canvassing the globe to illustrate the deadly consequences of our warming world.
content: “Open your eyes. We have failed. The climate crisis is now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A Tribe’s Bitter Purge Brings an Unusual Request: Federal Intervention
description: After cutting 306 people from its rolls, the Nooksack tribe is moving to evict those who remain in tribal housing. The dispute has raised questions about individual rights and tribal sovereignty.
content: EVERSON, Wash. — In the snow-packed driveway of Saturnino Javier’s home, a dozen extended family members gathered last week with drums formed from cedar and animal skin, intoning the prayerful songs they had learned growing up in the Nooksack Indian Tribe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: 10 New Year’s Resolutions That Are Good for the Soul
description: There is hope in the idea that we can change, as individuals and as a society.
content: I accomplished zero percent of my New Year’s resolutions last year. I’m obviously no sage of discipline. But I’d argue that the chief value of resolutions is not found in our success or failure at keeping them. Instead, they help us reflect on what our lives are like, what we would like them to be like and what practices might bridge the difference. There is goodness then in the very process of making resolutions. There is hope in the idea that we can change — that we can keep growing, learning and trying new things. This hope of renewal is the point of resolutions for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Antonio Brown Storms Off Field During Buccaneers’ Win Over Jets
description: The receiver shed his jersey, threw it into the stands and left. Afterward, Tampa Bay Coach Bruce Arians said, “He is no longer a Buc.”
content: Tampa Bay Buccaneers wide receiver Antonio Brown oddly and abruptly left his team’s sideline and went to the locker room with his team losing to the Jets on Sunday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: How Much for That Doggie in the Cubicle?
description: Everyone needs a little boundary training.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: New York reports 85,000 cases in a day, another record, as surge shows no sign of slowing.
description: New York State recorded over 85,000 new coronavirus cases on the last day of 2021, the highest one-day total in the state since the pandemic began, officials announced on Saturday.
content: New York State recorded over 85,000 new coronavirus cases on the last day of 2021, the highest one-day total in the state since the pandemic began, officials announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Monika Pronczuk
title: Europe Plans to Say Nuclear Power and Natural Gas Are Green Investments
description: The draft proposal could help unleash a wave of investment, but critics say both sources of energy cause damage to the environment.
content: The European Union has drawn up plans to classify some nuclear power and natural gas plants as green investments that can help Europe cut planet-warming emissions, a landmark proposal that, if approved, could set off a resurgence of nuclear energy on the continent in the coming decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Yancy
title: What I Learned About Death From 7 Religious Scholars, 1 Atheist and My Father
description: There is so much to learn from facing the about what is unknowable.
content: Just a few days before my father died in 2014, I asked him a question some might find insensitive or inappropriate:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In the Tinderbox of Bosnia, a Serb Nationalist Lights a Match
description: Bosnia’s fragile multiethnic government is facing its greatest crisis since the Balkan wars. The Serb nationalist leader, Milorad Dodik, is threatening to tear the country apart.
content: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — When Bosnia’s medicines agency inspected oxygen sold to hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients in the country’s Serb-controlled region in September, it made a shocking discovery: The oxygen was meant for use only in industrial machines, not on human beings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 10, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Note: A moderated discussion about this photograph will take place on Monday, Jan. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Stephanie Saul, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith
title: Americans are bracing for the return to school and work.
description: In two short weeks, as 2021 closed out, the Omicron variant drove coronavirus case counts to record levels, upended air travel and left gaping staffing holes at police departments, firehouses and hospitals.
content: In two short weeks, as 2021 closed out, the Omicron variant drove coronavirus case counts to record levels, upended air travel and left gaping staffing holes at police departments, firehouses and hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: NASA’s Retiring Top Scientist Says We Can Terraform Mars and Maybe Venus, Too
description: Jim Green has shaped much of the space agency’s scientific inquiry for decades.
content: Since joining NASA in 1980, Jim Green has seen it all. He has helped the space agency understand Earth’s magnetic field, explore the outer solar system and search for life on Mars. As the new year arrived on Saturday, he bade farewell to the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Back to School and Work Even as Omicron Explodes
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 2, 2022.
content: “I figured that over these two weeks of break, everyone has been everywhere visiting everybody. So I really just anticipate January to be a disaster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen and Kate Kelly
title: James Cayne, Who Ran the Ill-Fated Bear Stearns, Dies at 87
description: The first Wall Street chief to own a company stake worth more than $1 billion, he steered the company to five years of record profits before it suffered huge losses in 2007.
content: James Cayne, who was the chief executive of the investment bank Bear Stearns as it lurched into the global financial crisis, died on Tuesday in Long Branch, N.J. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Friend and I Decided to Grab Some Cupcakes Before Going Home’
description: A sweet cultural exchange, a happy landing at J.F.K. and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Twitter Permanently Suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Account
description: The social media service said the Republican congresswoman had violated its policy on coronavirus misinformation.
content: Twitter on Sunday permanently suspended the personal account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican of Georgia, after the company said she had violated its Covid-19 misinformation policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China Moves to Overhaul Protections for Women’s Rights, Sort Of
description: The proposed revisions to a women’s rights law would be the first major changes in nearly 20 years. But many women are skeptical that real progress will follow.
content: The announcement was presented — in official news reports, on social media — as a major victory for Chinese women. The government was set to overhaul its law governing women’s rights for the first time in decades, to refine the definition of sexual harassment, affirm prohibitions on workplace discrimination and ban forms of emotional abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Noah Hawley Keeps Changing Lanes
description: The show runner behind “Fargo” and “Legion” is also a novelist. His latest, “Anthem,” is set in a divided America with a touch of magical realism.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Noah Hawley tries never to approach a story the same way twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Hockey Fan Spots Cancerous Mole at Game and Delivers a Lifesaving Note
description: Nadia Popovici wrote a message on her phone, with “mole,” “cancer” and “doctor” in bright-red type to get the attention of Brian Hamilton, an assistant equipment manager for the Vancouver Canucks.
content: Nadia Popovici kept shifting her eyes from the hockey game to the back of Brian Hamilton’s neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Austin Ramzy
title: South African Parliament Buildings ‘Gutted’ After Large Fire
description: Officials warned that the damage to the buildings would be extensive. A man was arrested on Sunday morning inside the parliamentary complex, Parliament’s spokesman said.
content: CAPE TOWN — A large fire at South Africa’s Houses of Parliament on Sunday sent flames and smoke billowing from rooftops and fire crews racing to save the historic structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Reports 87% Increase in 2021 Deliveries
description: The electric-car maker managed substantial growth as Europe and China increasingly propelled sales.
content: Tesla reported Sunday that it delivered 936,000 cars in 2021, an 87 percent increase from the year before, despite the computer chip shortage that has disrupted auto production around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilbert Cruz
title: The Video Games That Got Us Through 2021
description: These are not the year’s best video games, and some of them aren’t even that new. But they are the ones that helped us through yet another unexpected year.
content: The year in video games was good, bad and everything in between. It remained difficult to purchase new consoles like the Xbox Series X, the Nintendo Switch OLED and the PlayStation 5. (One fine day, we’ll play Deathloop.) Cloud gaming continued to grow in importance and Roblox continued to dominate. And, as a result of lawsuits or employee unrest, game industry giants like Activision and Riot Games were forced to confront their terrible records on sexual harassment and gender discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: Amid Omicron, the Met Opera Opens a Weimar ‘Rigoletto’
description: Quinn Kelsey and Rosa Feola lead a superb cast in Bartlett Sher’s new staging of Verdi’s classic drama.
content: While a surge of coronavirus cases, driven by the spread of the Omicron variant, has taken a profound toll on live performance in New York, the Metropolitan Opera has not yet canceled a performance. The company was so determined not to lose the premiere of its new production of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” that at the final dress rehearsal, on Tuesday, everyone onstage wore a medical mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Mrs. Doubtfire’ on Broadway Is Pausing to Avoid Closing
description: The musical’s producer, eager to avoid a permanent shutdown amid the virus surge, is attempting a self-imposed nine-week hiatus.
content: In a startling illustration of the financial damage a resurgent pandemic is causing on Broadway, the producer of a new musical adaptation of “Mrs. Doubtfire” has decided to close down his show for nine weeks, saying he sees no other way to save the production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Left and Center-Left Both Claim Stacey Abrams. Who’s Right?
description: Ms. Abrams, the Georgia Democrat running for governor, has admirers in both wings of her party — and Republicans eager to defeat her. Her carefully calibrated strategy faces a test in 2022.
content: To left-leaning Democrats, Stacey Abrams, who is making her second run for Georgia governor, is a superstar: a nationally recognized voting-rights champion, a symbol of her state’s changing demographics, and a political visionary who registered and mobilized tens of thousands of new voters — the kind of grass-roots organizing that progressives have long preached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne-Marie Jackson
title: These Novels Are Asking You to Read More, and Read Better
description: African literature’s big year is a tantalizing invitation to readers.
content: Everyone is saying it: 2021 was the year for African literature. Writers from the continent scooped the Nobel, Booker, Goncourt and Camões prizes. And these honors — arguably the highest-sheen literary awards in the world — do not make up even half the list. The Neustadt, or “American Nobel,” and International Booker Prizes went to Senegalese writers, and the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade to a Zimbabwean one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 2, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 2, 2022.
content: An article this weekend on Page 15 about the painter and illustrator Doris Lee misstates her birth year. It was 1904, not 1905 (although the artist went by 1905). It also misstates the surname of Milton Avery’s wife. She was Sally Michel, not Michael. And it misstates the year the dealer Deedee Wigmore began representing Doris Lee’s estate. It was 1990, not 1991.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Team Owner Surprises Workers With ‘Life-Changing Gesture’ After Sale
description: The owner of the Iowa Cubs gave employees $2,000 for every year they had been with the minor league baseball team, for a total of $600,000. “My jaw dropped,” one worker said.
content: Three days after Christmas, Michael Gartner summoned the employees of the Iowa Cubs minor league baseball team to a staff meeting at Principal Park, the team’s stadium in Des Moines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Coming Soon to This Coal County: Solar, in a Big Way
description: In Martin County, Ky., where coal production has flatlined, entrepreneurs are promising that a new solar farm atop a shuttered mine will bring green energy jobs.
content: MARTIN COUNTY, Ky. — For a mountain that’s had its top blown off, the old Martiki coal mine is looking especially winsome these days. With its vast stretches of emerald grass dotted with hay bales and ringed with blue-tinged peaks, and the wild horses and cattle that roam there, it looks less like a shuttered strip mine and more like an ad for organic milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Dolphins Revealed as Playoff Pretenders by Tennessee
description: The Miami Dolphins were on the brink of being eliminated, and later officially so, despite winning seven in a row this season. Of course, they also lost seven in a row this season.
content: NASHVILLE — In some vocations, being merely average is neither advisable nor tolerated. Like neurosurgery. Or air-traffic control. But in the N.F.L., mediocrity isn’t just welcomed — it’s rewarded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan’s Prime Minister, Abdalla Hamdok, Resigns
description: Mr. Hamdok was restored to power a month ago after being deposed in a coup, but he was never able to gain control of the fractious country.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudan’s prime minister, who was ousted in a military coup but reinstated over a month ago, resigned on Sunday, in the latest upheaval to disrupt the country’s shaky transition to democracy from dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: A Spanish Mystery: Is a ‘Masked Restorer’ to Blame for a Church’s Botched Repair?
description: Yet another imprudent fix in a land plagued by vigilante handymen led to angry calls to find the culprit — and to a soul-searching question: Does Spain just have too much history in need of upkeep?
content: CASTRONUÑO, Spain — The Romanesque church that sits above the river in the Spanish village of Castronuño used to look like many others that dot the land: not too decrepit for a 750-year-old, but not particularly well-kept either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Kevin Quealy
title: Each N.F.L. Team’s Playoff Path: Week 17
description: A team-by-team guide to the N.F.L. playoff picture through Week 17.
content: A team-by-team guide to the N.F.L. playoff picture through Week 17.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Challenges of Keeping Schools Open
description: Readers discuss the teacher shortage and conditions in inner-city schools. Also: The nuclear threat; saving the free press; Meredith Willson.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start the year with a winter vegetable curry, a comforting pasta or salmon burgers.
content: Good morning. I’m not a data scientist but I know a little bit. This is the season of pledges and hope, of new lifestyle choices, crossed hearts and pinky swears: less animal protein on the plate this year; more vegetables and whole grains; regular exercise; Dryuary; the whole healthy shebang. I’d no more recommend fried chicken for dinner tonight as suggest you pair it with Mountain Dew and a Marlboro for dessert. It’s been nearly two years of video meetings, but I can still read a room.
source.name: The New York Times
